The city is located next to the Cobalita River and much is very low ground, actually a mangrove swamp which is under water during the rainy season.  The uncovered and restored structures are not as impressive as those at other sites but interesting none the less.

What makes Cobalita so spectacular however is the view from cliff tops, reached from an easily travelled path.  Endless beach bordering the Pacific Ocean.  To the south is the mouth of the Cobalita River, which at this point in the season barely makes it to the ocean.  There were several bird enthusiasts at this overlook one of whom pointed out an eagle perched on a log in the river and eating a fish it has just caught.  To the immediate north is a resort sitting atop the cliffs.  All in all a magnificent view.

After coming down from the cliff tops, visitors can walk along several paths through the site. There is also a small but interesting museum.  While I wouldn't make a special trip to Huatulco just to visit Cobalita, it is a pleasant way to spend an hour or two as part of a sea side vacation and should be seen.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

552608375.name: The view of the ocean was spectacular when we walked up to the lookout.
552608375.author: a TripAdvisor user
552608375.reviewBody: Lots of 20-30 wild, black vultures were flying around the cliffs and tall old trees as we headed for the lookout. It was a hot, sunny day, and the ocean was reflecting the sun as a mirror.            Huge rock formations were standing close to the edge of the water. The waves were white and majestic as they hit these piles of rocks. We were quite high above the beach. but we could observe hundreds of water birds as the delta of the river offered them lots of food.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

549366092.name: Much better then expected
549366092.author: a TripAdvisor user
549366092.reviewBody: This site was a 40 minute walk from Secrets. We loved everything about it. They have a very nice museum ( could have used a english translation). The walk thru the site was entirely in shade. Make sure you finish at the highest point overlooking the Ocean for  great pics of Bocana Beach.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

545818217.name: Ruins and walk to overlook
545818217.author: a TripAdvisor user
545818217.reviewBody: Stopped here as part of a cruise tour.  It was a good hike up to the overlook which has great views of the ocean and beach.  Walking back down was difficult as the walkway steps are on a slant - awkward.  The limited ruins were interesting to see.  Our tour guide though provided limited information on that and tended to talk only about the local animals and plants - limited history.  The place appears run down and many of the signs with information were rusted and falling apart.  The visitor center had interesting artifacts with all the information in Spanish only.  Good chance for me to practice my translation skills.  I enjoyed the tour but it wasn\'t anything spectacular.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

544848277.name: A great morning
544848277.author: a TripAdvisor user
544848277.reviewBody: The pathways through the trees lead you to the excavations with signs explaining each rocky mound. Along the pathways the descriptions are in English as well as spanish but inside the museum is Spanish only. If you are a person needing the details and not doing well in the local language you may like to employ a guide (about 500 pesos)\nThe butterflies are amazing as are the species of foliage.\nGo in the morning, take water and mosquito repellant, bring your camera.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

543883496.name: Small site on the coast well worth your time
543883496.author: a TripAdvisor user
543883496.reviewBody:
The Copalita site now has been set up for visitors—shady mostly paved pathways, and an interesting museum. At a stop by a lake everyone was fascinated with the iguanas and duck-billed herons. Our guide, Mario,  had a birding scope which added to his thorough knowledge and presentation. 

Mario says there are archeological sites up and down the coast, which makes sense. They are actively excavating this one but of course without sufficient funds to make rapid progress.

We did not have time to make the climb--that would require physical energy as reported by other reviewers.

The site is a ten minute taxi ride from Las Brisas. No food service as yet.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

461322302.name: One of the best archaelogical sites in Mexico
461322302.author: a TripAdvisor user
461322302.reviewBody: The Eco-Archaeological Copalita Park is excellent.  The small museum is informative and sophisticated.  The paths are well developed and maintained.  The ruins are in early stages of being excavated and preserved, so it is special to stroll through the tropical jungle and wetland with a focus on the structural remains of the civilization dating back to 900 A.D.  For history or nature buffs this is a must see.\nMy husband and I hired a taxi from the Dreams resort to the ruins for $5.  Our taxi did not return even though we had set a return time.  I strongly suggest that arrangements be made through the information desk.  (I am not sure there is personal cell service).  Plan on 5-10 minutes for arrival after the call\n

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

456666122.name: A Wonderful Little Pre-Hispanic Site
456666122.author: a TripAdvisor user
456666122.reviewBody: We have been coming to Huatulco for many years.  The first time I was there was in 1976... To reach it it took me over 4 hours by dirt road from the last paved road in Pochutla.  Just a little fishing village on one of the bays... you could rent a hammock on the beach, no hotels like now.  Through the years we\'ve seen it develop and have always enjoyed the area.  Through the years we often at at the small restaurants in Bocana Copalita not knowing that there was an archaeological site on the hillside above us.  This site has been developed into a wonderful facility with a small, modern museum.  The modern facilities are well laid out, attractive and new.  Very nice.  You then walk through tree covered trails, around ruins and through different habitats.  Various species of wildlife are all around.  At the end of the trail there are a series of steps up a hillside that rewards you with spectacular views along a walk on the edge of the cliff face.  All in all a wonderful way to spend some time in Huatulco when not on the beach!  One suggestion is that the museum displays should have English translations as well as the Spanish.  There are also several trails that "dead end" but appear that there are plans to continued them in the future.   I look forward to that time and the next time we\'re back in Huatulco!!!

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

454612110.name: Very Interesting
454612110.author: a TripAdvisor user
454612110.reviewBody: Would recommend this to anyone visiting Huatulco. Took bug repellent after reading other reviews but didn\'t come across any. Must depend on the time of year. Beautiful view from the top of the trail, definitely take a camera. No problem in flip-flops. Maybe difficult to get up to the top unless you are in good shape. Not a dirt path - all flat rock and cement trail. Museum very interesting. Signs in museum are all in Spanish - to keep the tour guides working I think. All signs along the trails and archeological sites are English and Spanish. Ran into a couple that had an app on the cellphone that translated the Spanish into English when you pointed cellphone at the Spanish signs! Also we took a cab there and when visit was over the front desk will call you a cab.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

443501890.name: Nice little site view and museum!
443501890.author: a TripAdvisor user
443501890.reviewBody: It\'s a small site only 3 temples and one was closed at the beginning is a new museum some interesting  artefacts but only written in Spanish. But along the trail is translated in English for some back ground on this old site. Then the view at the top is a treat where the river meets the ocean with lots of birds. There\'s also a wetland area again with birds. The path is easy to get around a small hike to the top and is all in overgrown old trees. Takes 1-2 hours for the whole site. I took a collectivo from la Cruzcieta with the sign Copolita and again from the road the collectivo back 15 pesos each way and 80 pesos to get in so not an expensive half day trip.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

435456230.name: Coping at Copalita
435456230.author: a TripAdvisor user
435456230.reviewBody: We visited the site in late September 2016 and for a site that is still work in progress, I thought it was very interesting. It was still in the morning that we visited and the temperature and humidity were comfortable. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable, but his English left a little to be desired. I helped interpret what he was saying to two German couples. I\'m glad I was good with German. The icing on the cake was to climb up to the top at the cliffs and look out at the ocean. Beautiful and peaceful area.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

402827146.name: Great way to spend a morning
402827146.author: a TripAdvisor user
402827146.reviewBody: We came here March 2016. Great way to spend a morning! As usual for Huatulco, very, very hot and unforgiving sun, so I would suggest an earlier visit rather than mid day. \nSuper cheap to get in, handed a map and sent off on our own to explore. The paths were beautiful, the one spot to get up to the end over looking the ocean is quite a few stairs. Worth the hike if you\'re able to make it though. Can see from one of the beach down to La Bocana(where we stopped for some much needed beers on the way back to Secrets!)\nThey were still working on some of the other sites that are yet to be opened. Looking forward to returning in the future!

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

377131479.name: Seen Better
377131479.author: a TripAdvisor user
377131479.reviewBody: The paths provide a nice walk with some pretty plants. On the archaeological side, I was disappointed. There are only a couple of stacked stone structures and workers were creating other stacked stone areas while we were there. It all seemed staged.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

365690031.name: Nice walk on the beach
365690031.author: a TripAdvisor user
365690031.reviewBody: We were able to walk here from the Secrets resort.  It took about 20 minutes.  The town is a little surf village  and you can have lunch and a drink.  The surfing is excellent and the beach is flat with very fine sand.  The river is about 3-400 meters south and opens up into a brackish pond.  Lots of birds.  A great place to walk, run a dog, throw sticks etc..

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

356435435.name: A true gem close to Huatulco
356435435.author: a TripAdvisor user
356435435.reviewBody: We visited the Ecological park and archeology site in March 2016. This is really a beautiful spot and so close to town. You can easily reach it by taxi, and there are folks who can guide you around, or you can just use the map you get at the entrance to walk the very well maintained paths under the shady trees. There are temple sites, to pass by and a wonderful hike (in the sun) to a stunning lookout over the coastline. Lots of interpretive signs in both Spanish and English. There is also a small museum with some interesting artifacts, but only Spanish explanations. Well worth a visit and the 80 peso entrance fee.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

354297532.author: a TripAdvisor user
354297532.reviewBody:
Went just before closing 
Walked around by ourselves
When asked for guide, were told no guide, tried to ask if other days and didn't, understand
Agree beautiful view and some birds but would have liked to learn more

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

347124277.name: Fascinating Museum and Archaeological site.
347124277.author: a TripAdvisor user
347124277.reviewBody: This trip takes about 3 hours, the site was only discovered about 15 years ago when a developer accidentally uncovered a temple. Since then the site has been explored where it revealed 2 temples and a game site. A museum has been constructed in a very attractive design to display many of the artifacts that were discovered and walk ways have been built to a very high standard to facilitate walking around the site, this alone makes a visit worthwhile since the paths are well shaded and offer views of interesting vegetation before arriving at a lookout overlooking the beach and the Copalita river.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

334674090.name: Unforgotable view
334674090.author: a TripAdvisor user
334674090.reviewBody: Magic location full of archeological structures, mysterious walkways and the best view of the river delta and the Pacific Ocean. It is completely worth the walk.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

331053243.name: Ask for Mario!
331053243.author: a TripAdvisor user
331053243.reviewBody: Have visited this site five times with different groups of friends each time, always been a positive reaction from our amigos. We were lucky enough to meet tour guide Mario Parga the first trip, and have "booked" our site tours with him each time since. I swear this man knows EVERY bug, plant and animal on a first name basis! The park itself has a half dozen or more microclimates within it, so a botanist\'s and bird watcher\'s dream. We have watched the "glass house" exhibition be built and opened and filled with items and calendars, and are still amazed with the beauty of the artifacts. I hope that Fonatur will either put up English translated info cards, or maybe do a fold out tour brochure in English about the contents of the building, soon. *DO* take the walk up the hill to see the breathtaking ocean vistas from the veiwpoints. When you visit La Bocana on another day, you can look back up the cliffs to where you were and say "I was there"! The mouth of the river has changed every visit we have made. This is a worthwhile thing to do, do go earlier in the morning, much cooler and more comfortable. A great place to begin your understanding of the rich history of the wonderful Mixteca and Zapoteca indigenous people.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

304113105.name: A little bit of History in Huatulco
304113105.author: a TripAdvisor user
304113105.reviewBody: A nice tour of the history in the area. Very shady so you can see all the ruins and viewpoints without all the heat. Very affordable as well and staff along the path to help guide you.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

284352324.name: Do not miss this.   It will be one of the highlights of your trip.
284352324.author: a TripAdvisor user
284352324.reviewBody: From a magnificent small museum to a stroll through the archaeological park and its uncovered ruins dating to 400 BC, to views of La Bocana, the mouth of the Copalita river and the ocean, this place is magical.   A modest entry fee will get you in.   For a separate fee, you can travel with a bi-lingual, licensed guide who knows the area and will point out things you\'d otherwise see.    When you\'re done, exit onto Highway 200, walk west about 1/4 mile to La Bocana.   You\'ll find several inviting restaurants (the place on the left abutting the beach is our favorite) with cold drinks and a very nice seafood menu.   While their shrimp empanazada and shrimp cocktails are awesome, their fish burger (not on the menu but always available) is memorable.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

278044789.name: Copalita Archeological park a must see
278044789.author: a TripAdvisor user
278044789.reviewBody:
Spent a morning at the Copalita Archeological park and enjoyed every minute.  From the ride along the coast (MX$ 80 from our home in Arrocito Bay) to the walks among the ruins, everything was stunning.  We joined a guided tour with offered by Cornelio Ramos Gabriel, and were glad we did.  Guides offer additional context, information, and even point out sites and sounds that the casual uninformed visitor may (likely) miss.  The tour itself was approximately 2 hours in length, during which we saw the ruins, wildlife, and visited the observation points to the river Copalita and the Ocean.  Cornelio is a professional guide offering other services and tours, and we will be following up with him about some of them, as his manner and style were both relaxing and informative.

The park itself is within a wooded area, and stepping out onto the two observation points really highlights how cool the forest is, and how it offers a nice respite from the sun and heat.

Well worth the visit.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

273632873.name: A nice morning side trip while in Huatulco
273632873.author: a TripAdvisor user
273632873.reviewBody: I confess, we are jaded.  We\'ve been to almost every ruin in Central and South America, and this one is not very memorable, although the facilities were very nice, and the mosquitoes were spectacular.  Take water, and lots and lots of bug juice!!!!

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

260307663.name: Guide had good knowledge of history
260307663.author: a TripAdvisor user
260307663.reviewBody: An enjoyable small site with a very nice small museum. Go early and hire a guide at the front entrance. or join with another group and the cost is less. They will take you through the museum and  explain The history of the  people and explain the significance of all the artifacts found in the area it was very interesting. We then went for a walk through the park area very and near the end there was a bit of a hike ip to the top of the ridge---- take it slow if you need to but the view from the top is fantastic. You can look look down on Bocana Beach and see where the Ocean flows into the  Copalita river a very unique site .

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

260220396.name: Well worth the visit
260220396.author: a TripAdvisor user
260220396.reviewBody: Great opportunity to find out about the Zapotec civilization that dominated the area prior to the arrival of the Europeans. The ruins are very interesting and well marked in both Spanish and English. Certainly not as "big" as the Mayan ruins in the Yucatan, but just the same very interesting. The displays at the beginning are fascinating to see all the relics and the air-conditioned building, very architectually pleasing. The hike up to the viewpoint above La Bocana beach is breath-taking and easily do-able for this old fart. Expect 2 hours or so for the site. There was hardly anyone there the day we went, maybe 20 people.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

259299887.name: Interesting place
259299887.author: a TripAdvisor user
259299887.reviewBody: If you like history and a bit of hiking with great views this is worth the drive. The museum can be hot but once out in the park it is lovely.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

257921321.name: awesome viewpoint
257921321.author: a TripAdvisor user
257921321.reviewBody: An awesome walk through the jungle and ruins on probably the best laid out stone path in Huatulco, actually wheelchair accessable, although going up to the viewpoint would be a real tough haul. The viewpoint overlooking the ocean at La Bocana is one to behold. The entrance price is 80 ps per person plus a 5 ps cost for a locker. You can hire a guide if you like but they are fairly expensive. Otherwise there is lots of info posted everywhere, although only in Spanish in the actual museum. Overall, we spent close to 3 hours here: I\'d recommend an early start though. There are snacks and drinks in machines.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

252968804.name: A Beautiful and Rewarding Location
252968804.author: a TripAdvisor user
252968804.reviewBody: The museum is modern and beautifully cared for with some exquisite displays.  The trails around the main archaeological site are wide, clear and mostly flat providing easy access to some interesting ruins with more being prepared for future display. This is a great site to visit to learn of the ancient ways in this region of Mexico and it is newly opened to the public with modern conveniences. The trail to climb from the ruins to the sea and the vista point is a bit steep but well worth it...maybe 30 minutes total for an awesome view. Definitely not as steep as the Parthenon!\n\nWe are daily hikers and archaeology fans...this visit was a major hit with us...we learned about culture that we have never studied. Highly recommend...safe and rewarding!

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

252908913.name: An interesting tour
252908913.author: a TripAdvisor user
252908913.reviewBody: Great tour, easy to get to. Ruins are  newly discovered with some in the process of being excavated. Good to use a guide as displays are in Spanish. Beautiful  views of the river and ocean, a must see.\n\nAndy &  Bonnie  Canada

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

252461189.name: Great but bring insect repellent!!!
252461189.author: a TripAdvisor user
252461189.reviewBody: Took a taxi here from our hotel - a few kms I guess, cost 70 pesos or thereabouts. When we arrived there was a sign saying insect repellent is essential, and we had forgotten ours. Luckily a tour guide let us use his spray. Despite this we were plagued by mosquitos and seemed to constantly have a swarm of them behind us (we were there in September, rainy season). Didn\'t help that it was very hot and we were sweating the repellent away - if you bring your own, and plenty, you will be fine! A highlight for me was seeing two baby iguanas - bright leaf-green - just behind the entrance and visitor centre. Walking around the jungle paths we saw the ruins - not the most spectacular in Mexico by any means but interesting to see the prehispanic settlements and get away from the beaches for a change. Some of the paths were closed for the rainy season as they were very slippery so we couldn\'t get as close as we would have liked. Following the path there are nice views over the river estuary and beaches. I would recommend a trip here for its touch of prehispanic history (there is a small one-room museum), the views of the river mouth and the chance to explore a tiny bit of the jungle.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

248677162.reviewBody: This is a very small archaeological site but it has a lovely trail through the woods which was good for bird watching.  We saw army ants in action, saw a coati mundi, and a porcupine as well as quite a variety of birds (including the always interesting boatbilled heron).

234484466.name: Extremely satisfied with Arturo Martinez
234484466.author: a TripAdvisor user
234484466.reviewBody: Arturomartinez16@hotmail.comust get back a few days ago cruising through the panama canal. We had private tour with Arturo to the archeological side, mazcal testing and I bought a few hand woowen hight quality bedsheets and rug (Huatalco, well known for). We had typical Mexican food.  Never seen anyone like Arturo, he\'s very passionate about what he\'s doing. He\'s a certified tour guide. He make sure we understand the history, at the same time making sure we have fun and safe. Don\'t book your tour with cruise it\'s a ripped off. Strongly recommend Arturo the price is right and you get personalised service.\nArturomartinez16@hotmail.com

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

212802625.name: Not sure about the hype...
212802625.author: a TripAdvisor user
212802625.reviewBody:
I think I may have liked this place better if I knew what to expect.  First off, people were mentioning the "mud baths."  We got there and no one knew what I was talking about when we asked, they said that didn't exist.  There are these buildings when you first come up that were closed, and didn't look like there was any intention of opening again... maybe that is where those were?  

It was a pretty hike, but that is what you should expect.  You can go up this cliff and see a great view of the ocean.  The ruins are not what I expected from other places... If you are really into archaeology and anthropology, you may love it... but if you want to see something cool on a vacation, this may be something to skip. 

A tip- it isn't crowded at all, so no cabs come here, make sure you make a deal with your cab driver to pick you up when you are done too.  2 hours was perfect for us to walk all of the paths, and check out the museum.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

158481915.name: Enjoy the beach at La Bocana too!
158481915.author: a TripAdvisor user
158481915.reviewBody:
The Copalita ruins and ecological park are a good daytrip.  The museum is top notch, the ruins are very small, but the hike is wonderful.  Going out is all uphill, so take water and take it easy.  The boardwalks and staircases are pretty cool, and the views of the ocean near the end are just lovely.  We had an overcast day, so it wasn't too hot, but on a sunny day go early!!!

What we missed on our first visit was the fantastic beach at La Bocana.  If you see the eco park and ruins early in the day, then you'll have time to enjoy the fabulous surf and wildlife on the beach and maybe have a drink and snacks at one of the pretty beach palapas.

After the snorkeling and sunning beaches of Playa Entrega, Playa Santa Cruz and Tangolunda Bay, we found Playa La Bocana to be a sheer delight because it is so rugged, so wild and so different than the others.

We have so many pics it's easiest to share a link to our collection of photos from La Bocana:  http://roadslesstraveled.us/sailing-mexico-blog-playa-la-bocana-huatulco-mexico/

They are still in the process of expanding the site, we can\'t wait to go back and see more

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

155296466.name: A very nice experience
155296466.author: a TripAdvisor user
155296466.reviewBody: I had a wonderful time walking through this site.  The museum is small but very well done.  The interesting part for me was the walk through the whole site.  The view is unbelievable of the Rio Copalita as it runs into the ocean.  I was by myself and one of the employees who lives in the area walked me around and explained the archeological sites to me.  He was so sweet. He even came looking for me when I took a little longer than I should have on the walk.  I think this is an excellent choice to visit for anyone who likes archeology or just likes to walk and soak up nature.  Again--the views are awesome.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

150529166.name: Take in a Little Culture on Your Beach Vacation
150529166.author: a TripAdvisor user
150529166.reviewBody: The site is very well laid out, with bilingual signage.  Especially for those who have at least some interest in pre-Hispanic cultures, it is a must.  The signage explains the construction materials, in some cases distinct from those used to construct the sites in the state\'s central valleys.  There are also well marked pathways up to pinnacles providing exquisite vistas of the ocean below.  There are also explanations of the flora and fauna of the region on the signs.  A vist provides a great little break from the usual tourist attractions in and around Huatulco. The museum contains some exquisite archaelogical pieces.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

150311331.reviewBody: A very attractive area preserved in a natural state.  Imagine seeing nature preserved and feeling more knowledgible about the first humans in this part of Mexico.  Close to seeing, hearing and smelling what people in the past did.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

147611015.name: Pretty cool
147611015.author: a TripAdvisor user
147611015.reviewBody: It is a neat site to check out. My only complaint is that the room with all the artifacts all of the information was in Spanish. So if you only speak English you might want to pay extra for the guided tour. The ruins have both English and Spanish on the placards. It was 10 dollars per person and if you wanted the guided tour it was 30. There are beautiful viewpoints you can walk to, they are a must see. Make sure you bring a beverage along as it is an uphill path to the viewpoints and it is of course pretty warm. The paths are treed in and there are many cute little geckos to be seen along the way.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

122895072.name: Ruins and nature, near the ocean
122895072.author: a TripAdvisor user
122895072.reviewBody: It\'s all on a small scale. But quite enchanting. Lovely little museum with some well displayed archaeological items. Then broad, paved walks through the dry tropical forest down to the coast for a spectacular view over the Rio Copalita, and what is left of the La Bocana beach, after the river has washed most of it away! The forest is alive with birds, butterflies and the occasional sighting of snakes and other fauna. The part-reconstructed Mixtec ruins (and more would be welcome) give enough information for the viewer to guess how impressive it must all have been some 800 years ago. Again, going early by taxi, before the bus tours arrive, is a magic moment where the mystery of the Mixtecs will fascinate.\nIt needs a simple coffee shop (with local coffee and juices) to complete the complex and perhaps a notice board of the state of Oaxaca, pinpointing other archaeological areas that might be of interest to the traveller.

118763284.author: a TripAdvisor user
118763284.reviewBody: This prehispanic site offers you the view to see the history of the region and how life happened back then. Get some archeaological information before you go because there is none as well of a bottle of water. Is a good chance to see something more than beaches and you have a nice view from top of the cliff to see how the river meets the ocean. The park is close on mondays.

118032920.name: Bocana Del Rio Copalita, Beautiful, Cultural!
118032920.author: a TripAdvisor user
118032920.reviewBody: We went to Bocana del Rio Copalita on a morning when it was raining a bit. We got there just as they were opening. We chose not to have a guide, but to walk at our pace and take pictures. The paths are great, the signage can be a bit confusing, but they do give you a map. We did spend several hours there and really did not see the whole place. We did hike up to where you could overlook the ocean and see the Copalita River joining the ocean. Made for some wonderful pictures. For the Price, this is a must see. The Mexican Government has spent alot of money to develop this site.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

108394646.name: Touch of culture
108394646.author: a TripAdvisor user
108394646.reviewBody:
We were very interested in visiting the Archaeological site when dropped by on our taxi tour of the region.

Located about a 20 minute taxi ride from La Crucecita, it is a great way to spend about 2 hours.

The site itself is 5 Peso per person, and a tour guide can be arranged for about 250 peso.  Our guide (sorry can't remember his name) was very fluent in english and had a vast knowledge of both the site, pre-spanish history and natural fauna and flora.  We spent about 30 minutes in the museum looking at some amazing artifacts then about 1 hour walking the site.

The site itself is only about 1/3 uncovered and the main ruins will take another 2-3 years to be fully viewable.  That said, considering the park only opened in Oct 2010, there is an amazing about to see and visit.

Pay close attention to what is on the ground as we were able to find some interesting animals and insects.

The tour will take you through swamp areas, up into the desert, and onto the main cliff face where if the air is clear you'll see the river valley progress up into the Sierra mountains.

A great place to spend a few hours.

itemReviewed.name: Bocana del Rio Copalita Archaeological Zone

address.streetAddress: Blvd. Benito Juarez, near Playa La Bocana and the Copalita River

106724775.name: Get a bit of history and culture before hitting the beach
106724775.author: a TripAdvisor user
106724775.reviewBody:
Came to visit the archaelogical zone on our way to visit Playa La Bocana.  It is just a short distance on Blvd. Benito Juarez past the entrance to the beach.  Admission is 50 pesos/person.  You can hire a guide if you wish for about 200 pesos (or that was the price quoted to us).  We chose to just do the tour ourself.  There are paved walkways, most of it is in the shade.  By most of the reconstructed ruins, there are plaques which will tell you what each building/site is (or I should say, was).  It appears that perhaps it is not finished, as there are some areas that were roped off.  You can keep walking uphill to the lookout over the ocean which, to me, was worth the visit for that alone.  I heard you need to go early as it gets very hot.  We were there around 10:00 am; you are not in the sun and heat unless you do the climb to the lookout.  If you are not in good shape or have health problems, it could be a little difficult.  The climb to the lookout is NOT shaded so make sure you have water.  But the view from the top was incredible.  

There is also a museum on site; we did not go inside.  It was our first day and we were anxious to get to the beach.  It took us about 1-1/2 hours to see the entire site on our own and we hustled.  I'm sure a guide would have more information on each attraction.  Bathrooms are only at the entrance, by the museum; there are none on the path.  There are also storage lockers for a very nominal price. if you don't want to haul your stuff around.

From there, we walked down the road, about 15 minutes or so, to Playa La Bocana where we spent the rest of the day.  You can take a cab, but it definitely was walkable.  This is not far from the hotel zone, and it is a very nice park, lots of birds.  A nice cultural diversion from a beach destination.
